audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a woman speaking in an instructional tone, explaining how to examine the right side of the heart. She explains that she is going to open up the right side of the heart. She mentions two veins, the superior and inferior vena cava, and notes that the vessels feed into the right side of the heart.

A female speaker begins by describing how she is cutting along the probe to open up the right atrium. She notes that it's a small chamber, essentially an entrance into the heart for blood entering the right side. She proceeds to cut down along the edge of a wrinkle toward the apex to open up the right ventricle, explaining she will turn the heart upside down to do so. During this speech, her tone is instructional and deliberate. As she describes the apex, she reminds the audience that the right side of the heart does not include it, as it is part of the left ventricle.

The audio clip begins with a single female speaker preparing to "flip the heart back." She then proceeds to describe the right side of the heart, pointing out the right atrium and ventricle. She notes the ventricle's wall is thicker because it's a "stronger pump" compared to the thinner atrium wall. Throughout her explanation, the speaker maintains a factual and descriptive tone.

The audio clip features a single female speaker explaining the anatomy of the heart, specifically mentioning the valve between the right atrium and ventricle. She notes that the valve is made of a thin but strong material and prevents backflow, calling it the tricuspid valve. The speaker also describes "string-like structures" called chordae tendineae which prevent the valve from inverting. She finishes by mentioning the papillary muscles which hold the chordae tendineae in place. Her speaking tone is informative and matter-of-fact.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker describing the layers of the ventricle wall, mentioning the "major layers" visible on the wall, and naming the "epicardium," "myocardium," and "endocardium." The speaker has a calm and informative tone.

A female speaker begins, her tone informative and conversational, describing anatomical features, specifically a "feature coming across the right side of the heart" that "looks like a papillary muscle". She identifies a structure called the "moderator band", explaining that it "allows for electrical conduction to more efficiently get across the right side of the heart".

The clip features a single female speaker explaining the anatomy of the heart. She begins by noting that they will continue opening up the right side of the heart. She states they are seeing the "right atrium and the right ventricle." She goes on to describe how she will find the "major vessel that leads away from the right ventricle" and is carrying blood to the lungs. She mentions needing to "flip the heart over." She identifies the "pulmonary trunk" on the right side of the heart, and demonstrates how she is going to "put the probe down into the pulmonary trunk" to show how it attaches to the right ventricle. She flips the heart over again, observing that "that probe does in fact connect to the right ventricle" and that the vessel that she found "carries blood from the right ventricle up towards the lungs." Her tone is informative and descriptive throughout.

The clip begins with a female speaker referencing "an anterior view of the heart," and stating she will "finish opening up the right side of the heart" by cutting along the probe towards the right ventricle. She then says that she's going to turn the heart upside down. Sounds of cutting follow, then the speaker says, "Okay," before noting that the heart is right side up again.

The audio begins with a female speaker describing cutting through the right ventricle and opening it to view the inside of the pulmonary trunk. She points out the pulmonary trunk, noting it's a major artery carrying blood away from the right side of the heart towards the lungs. Her tone is informative and educational.

The audio begins with a single female speaker, in a calm, educational tone, pointing out "a little valve called the pulmonary semilunar valve". She then identifies "the right ventricle" and mentions a "moderator band" and notes a "better view of it here from the anterior side".

The audio clip begins with a female speaker stating that "moderator band allows electrical conduction across the right side of the heart." She continues, mentioning "another one of the cusps of the semilunar valve," as she puts the "probe down into it." The tone is informative and clinical.
